row.entry: These rules permit the court to order necessary answers to interrogatories. The rules require special reasons to order interrogatories in personal injury proceedings. The rules prescribe the permissible grounds of objection, and regulate the form of statements in answer, to interrogatories.
These provisions permit the court to require further answers to interrogatories. They also permit the court to sanction default by stay, dismissal or striking out.

entry.emph: Answers to interrogatories as evidence — Rule 22.6

row.entry: This rule regulates the admission of answers to interrogatories as evidence in proceedings.
This Part does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division or the DDT or the Industrial Relations Commission (when acting otherwise than as the Industrial Court): see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The rules require a specific order of the court to administer interrogatories. Subject to that change, the substance of the rules otherwise reproduces the effect of the former SCR PtÂ 24 and DCR Pt 22A. There was previously no procedure for administering interrogatories in the Local Court.
Admissibility and effect of answers to interrogatories ‥ [22.6.5]
Agents and servants — obligation to enquire of ‥ [22.3.20]
Agents and servants — obligation to enquire of former ‥ [22.3.25]
Answering the substance of the interrogatory without evasion ‥ [22.3.15]
Answers to interrogatories, admissible in proceedings ‥ [r 22.6]
Answers to interrogatories in other proceedings ‥ [22.6.10]
Capacity of the answer to advance a party’s case ‥ [22.1.20]
Collateral purposes — restriction against use of answers for ‥ [22.6.15]
Defamation proceedings — interrogatories as to state of mind ‥ [22.1.40]
Default in compliance with orders to answer interrogatories ‥ [r 22.5]
Interrogatories — relevance, necessity and special reasons discretion ‥ [22.1.10]
Law — interrogatories relating to matters of ‥ [22.1.70]
Objections to interrogatories — answers given “subject to objection” ‥ [22.2.15]
Personal injury cases, special reasons required ‥ [r 22.1(3)]
State of mind, purpose or motive ‥ [22.1.80]
The form of answers to interrogatories ‥ [22.3.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 22.1] r 22.1 Interrogatories (cf SCR Part 24, rules 1–6; DCR Part 22A, rules 1–6)

leg:heading.title: Interrogatories (cf SCR Part 24, rules 1–6; DCR Part 22A, rules 1–6)

p.text: At any stage of the proceedings, the court may order any party to answer specified interrogatories.
An application for such an order must be accompanied by a copy of the proposed interrogatories.
In the case of proceedings on:
a claim for damages arising out of the death of, or bodily injury to, any person, or
a claim for contribution in relation to damages so arising,
such an order is not to be made unless the court is satisfied that special reasons exist that justify the making of the order.
In any case, such an order is not to be made unless the court is satisfied that the order is necessary at the time it is made.
An order to answer interrogatories:
may require the answers to be given within a specified time, and
may require the answers, or any of them, to be verified by affidavit, and

in circumstances in which rule 35.3 authorises someone other than the party to whom the order is addressed to make the relevant affidavit, may specify the person to make the affidavit, or the persons from whom the person to make the affidavit may be chosen, in relation to the interrogatories or any of them.
The approved form is Form 21 : Interrogatories.

level.toc-caption: [22.1.10] Interrogatories — relevance, necessity and special reasons discretion

p.text: Legislation cited in [22.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA ssÂ 56–58.

heading.title: Interrogatories — relevance, necessity and special reasons discretion

p.text: Interrogatories may be ordered where they are “necessary” or, in personal injury cases, where they are justified by “special reasons” (as to which see [21.8.5] ). The starting point in the analysis these limitations require is that the proposed interrogatory must have a relevant association or connection with a matter in issue in the proceedings: Seidler v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 2 NSWLR 390 at 393Â ; Tiver v Tiver [1960] SASR 40 at 50; Attorney-General v Gaskill (1882) 20 Ch D 519Â . That connection includes both matters that may be directly probative of facts in issue and also matters that may be relevant to the determination of facts in issue: Potters Sulphide Ore Treatment Ltd v Sulphide Corp Ltd (1911) 13 CLR 101 at 110–111; 18 ALR 141 (patent — interrogatories not limited to proof of direct infringement); Sharpe v Smail (1975) 5 ALR 377; 49 ALJR 130 at 133Â ; American Flange & Manufacturing Co Inc v Rheem (Aust) Pty Ltd (No 2) [1965] NSWR 193 at 195Â ; Australian Blue Metal Ltd v Hughes [1960] NSWR 673Â . The width of the criterion of relevance obviously permits a large element of impressionistic judgment as to whether a sufficient connection exists in any particular case. Equally obviously, and particularly having regard to the imperatives imposed by CPA ssÂ 56–58 (ieÂ the overriding purpose criteria), sound practical judgment must be exercised to ensure that the interlocutory discretion to order interrogatories is exercised only to the extent that it is appropriate for the proper determination of the real issues in the particular proceedings. The specific requirement that interrogatories can only be ordered where they are “necessary” emphasises the practical judgment involved. In addition, the authorities include various general propositions that categorise different kinds of interrogatories and attempt to provide more particular guidance about the proper exercise of the discretion. Both the general concept of “necessity”, and the other general propositions, are discussed in the following notes.

In addition to the threshold requirement of sufficient relevance, the rule requires the court to be satisfied that an order to answer interrogatories is “necessary”. This criterion of necessity has been consistently interpreted as meaning “necessary in the interests of a fair trial”: Boyle v Downs [1979] 1 NSWLR 192 at 204–5Â ; Percy v General Motors-Holden’s Pty Ltd [1975] 1 NSWLR 289Â ; Griebart v Morris [1920] 1 KB 659Â (“necessary for disposing fairly of the cause or matter”); Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072Â (“reasonably required or legally ancillary”); Yamazaki v Mustaca [1999] NSWSC 1083; BC9907282 at [4]Â (“reasonably necessary for disposing fairly of the case”). So interpreted, the concept of “necessity” involves an assessment of a range of considerations, including the likely availability of probative evidence, the nature the proceedings, the contested issues and the particular information sought in the proposed interrogatories: see further [22.1.17] .
pedestrian accident — plaintiff with no memory and no eye witnesses — interrogatories as to details of accident: Griebart v Morris [1920] 1 KB 659Â ;
infant plaintiff — contemporaneous police statement by defendant — interrogatories as to accident details: Schutt v Queenan [2000] NSWCA 341; BC200007963 at [11]–[14]Â ;
fatal accident — widow’s claim — scope of available evidence unclear — error of principle in refusing interrogatories: Yamazaki v Mustaca [1999] NSWSC 1083; BC9907282Â ;

damages arising out of personal injury at school — evidentiary difficulties without interrogatories — order reasonably necessary for disposing fairly of the matter: Boyle v Downs [1979] 1 NSWLR 192 at 204–5Â ;
medical negligence claim — interrogatories relevant to diagnostic evaluation and professional expertise — necessary: Chong v Nguyen [2005] NSWSC 588; BC200507146 at [9]–[16]Â ;

medical negligence claim — interrogatories relating to doctor’s knowledge and diagnostic reasoning: Keating v South East Sydney Illawarra Area Health Service (NSWSC, HallÂ J, NoÂ 20232 of 2005, 7Â July 2006, unreported).
interrogatory requesting names of persons to whom defamatory statement was published — not necessary: White & Co v Credit Reform Assn [1905] 1 KB 653Â ;
interrogatory about intended meaning of defamatory statement — not necessary: Heaton v Goldney [1910] 1 KB 754Â ;
interrogatory that would require a party to provide an acknowledgement contrary to a pleaded limitation defence — not necessary: Lovell v Lovell [1970] 3 All ER 721; [1970] 1 WLR 1451Â ;
workplace related psychiatric injury — interrogatories substantially directed towards adequacy of discovery — no special reasons: Cavric v Cooper Lybrand (ACT) Ltd [2002] NSWSC 538; BC200203290Â ;

interrogatories to identify medical attendances by proposed adoptive parents — no issue of fitness — interrogatories intended to explore possibility of unfitness: Director-General, Dept of Community Services vÂ D (2006) 66 NSWLR 582; [2006] NSWSC 827; BC200606433Â .
Legislation cited in [22.1.17] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56–61.

The probability of directions being made under r 2.3(j) (which relates to the filing of affidavits and witness statements) may suggest that, prior to compliance with such an order, it may be difficult to satisfy the court that a proposed interrogatory is “necessary” — because of the possibility that the evidence sought by the interrogatory may be available at the hearing in any event: Venacom Pty Ltd v Morgan Brooks Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 46; BC200600493Â . But it is well accepted that interrogatories may be regarded as necessary if they relate to material matters whose proof would otherwise be difficult, or involve unreasonable costs: Lang v Australian Coastal Shipping Commission [1974] 2 NSWLR 70Â ; Haywood v Collaroy Services Beach Club Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1203; BC200510265Â (interrogatories relating to contractual arrangements with a third party building contractor). Consequently the true position, having regard to the general discretionary considerations mandated by ss 56–61 of the CPA, is that the ultimate likely availability of the evidence sought is a relevant, but not necessarily determinative, consideration: Keating v South East Sydney Illawarra Area Health Service (NSWSC, Hall J, No 20232 of 2005, 7 July 2006, unreported) at [17] (medical negligence claim — interrogatories relating to doctor’s knowledge and diagnostic reasoning). It is at least consistent with the mandates of those sections of the CPA to regard as “necessary” interrogatories that are directed to obtaining admissions (see [22.1.25] ), explaining the contents of documents (see [22.1.50] ) or that otherwise offer a realistic prospect of reducing the length and/or the cost of the proceedings — even where the interrogatories relate to matters that might otherwise be reasonably expected to be the subject of a witness’ evidence at a final hearing: see Re Gerard Cassegrain & Co Pty Ltd; Cassegrain v Gerard Cassegrain & Co Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 241; BC201102171Â atÂ [20]–[36] (breach of fiduciary duty claim — interrogatories to obtain admissions about the contents and circumstances of contentious disclosures to plaintiff).

level.toc-caption: [22.1.20] Capacity of the answer to advance a party’s case

heading.title: Capacity of the answer to advance a party’s case

p.text: Beyond these general considerations, and the illustrations provided by the cases applying them, there has been considerable variation in the approach taken in the cases to the proper scope of interrogatories. There is a line of cases, although they are generally confined to the early years of the judicature system, which assert that a party may interrogate as to facts which tend to support its own case, or impeach the case of its opponent, but not as to facts which support the opponent’s case: Hooton v Dalby [1907] 2 KB 18 at 21Â ; Green v Green (1912) 13 SR (NSW) 126 at 133Â ; Potters Sulphide Ore Treatment Ltd v Sulphide Corp Ltd (1911) 13 CLR 101 at 110–11; 18 ALR 141; Cumming v Matheson (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 339 at 342Â ; Sewers Cmrs of London v Glasse (1873) LR 15 Eq 302; Plymouth Mutual Co-op and Industrial Society Ltd v Traders’ Publishing Assn Ltd [1906] 1 KB 403Â . Thus it has been said that a party may interrogate as to the truth of the facts alleged in his own pleadings: Bidder v Bridges (1885) 29 Ch D 29Â ; but not as to the truth of the facts alleged in the other party’s pleadings: Johns v James (1879) 13 Ch D 370Â ; Booth v Attenborough (1900) 21 ALT 205Â . The distinction that is expressed in these cases is not always easy to make and it can lead to reasoning that is not altogether easy to support. In other jurisdictions it has been abolished as a ground of objection to interrogatories (Evidence Act 1958 (Vic) s 32A) and it is not one of the grounds of objection specified in r 22.2. The better view is simply that the real test is materiality and if the answer sought relates to a matter in question between the parties it is largely inconsequential which party’s case the particular fact tends to support — subject to the pre-condition that the interrogatory is also “necessary”. In that context the interrogating party need not show that the answers sought must support their case. The possibility of support is sufficient: Playfair v Cormack (1913) 9 DLR 455; provided the interrogatories are put bona fide: McFadzen v Liverpool Corp (1868) LR 3 Exch 279. If the interrogatory is sought for the genuine purpose of advancing the interrogating party’s case, it is not rendered unnecessary by the fact that the answer may also tend to disclose the interrogated party’s case: Whateley v Crowter (1855) 5 E & B 709; 119 ER 643.

One of the most important purposes of interrogatories is to assist the interrogating party prove its case (or make out its defence) by obtaining verified admissions that relate to the matters in issue — whether that relationship is direct; Osborne v Sparke (1907) 7 SR (NSW) 460; 24 WN (NSW) 106Â ; or indirect: Australian Blue Metal Ltd v Hughes [1960] NSWR 673Â ; Dunbar v Perc [1956] VLR 583Â ; and see Adams v Dickeson [1974] VR 77 at 79Â ; Green v Green (1912) 13 SR (NSW) 126Â ; Sutherland v British Dominions Land Settlement Corp [1926] 1 Ch 746. Because of this purpose, an interrogatory is not necessarily objectionable merely because its answer is already known to the interrogator: Attorney-General v Gaskill (1882) 20 Ch D 519Â , at 528; James v Davies (1883) 9 VLR (L) 140Â ; or because the interrogator has other means of proving the matter: Lyell v Kennedy (1883) 8 App Cas 217 at 228Â . Any answer may operate as an admission, and where the answers are made on behalf of a corporation, the answers will constitute admissions binding the corporation: Smith Kline & French Laboratories Ltd v Inter-Continental Pharmaceuticals (Aust) Pty Ltd (1969) 123 CLR 514; 43 ALJR 308Â (as to answers to interrogatories by a corporation see the notes to r 22.3). The admissions contained in the answers to interrogatories may be tendered in evidence and will relieve the interrogating party of the need to adduce direct evidence of the facts so admitted: Attorney-General v Gaskill (1882) 20 Ch D 519Â : see r 22.6 and [22.6.5].

There has been said to be a general rule that it is not proper to interrogate for the purpose of obtaining the actual words used in a conversation — as distinct from the substance or effect of what was said: Eade v Jacobs (1877) 3 Ex D 335 at 337Â ; Attorney-General v Gaskill (1882) 20 Ch D 519Â ; West v Conway (1923) 23 SR (NSW) 344 at 346Â ; Permanent Finance Corp Ltd v Europacific (Plant Hire) Pty Ltd [1970] QWN 45Â . However the accuracy of this general rule is doubtful. Interrogatories have been allowed for the purpose of determining the identity of a particular speaker (Permanent Finance Corp Ltd v Europacific (Plant Hire) Pty Ltd , above) and as to whether particular (allegedly defamatory) words were spoken: Tournier v National Provincial and Union Bank of England [1924] 1 KB 461 at 477Â ; Daily Telegraph Newspaper Co Ltd v Berry (1879) 5 VLR (L) 343Â . An interrogatory seeking the actual terms of the conversation seems not to be materially different in kind. It is also relevant to consider that if the question were asked at the trial the interrogator could, to a degree, require the answer being given to the best of the witness’s recollection and in direct speech: Commonwealth v Riley (1984) 5 FCR 8; 57 ALR 249Â and LMI Australasia Pty Ltd v Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 31; [2001] NSWSC 688; BC200104748Â ). Since this is the position that would prevail at the trial, the basis for rejecting a similar interrogatory is questionable. If there is a general rule that restricts interrogatories about the actual words used in conversations, it may well be derived from a combination of practical considerations. First, there is a reluctance to allow interrogatories whose principal motive is to provide a basis for cross-examination if the trial evidence does not correspond precisely with the answers: Ryan v Federal Capital Press of Australia Pty Ltd (1990) 101 FLR 396Â . Second, there is the consideration that the interrogatories may be in the nature of requests for particulars. Where that is the case, it will not usually be “necessary” for the interrogator to insist upon the answers being given in direct speech. Third, the purpose of the interrogatory may be to obtain an admission about the substance of the conversation. Again it will not usually be “necessary” to require the answer to be given in direct speech. But, aside from these various practical considerations, if the actual words used in a particular conversation are material to the proceedings and the requirements of necessity are otherwise satisfied, it is difficult to justify the general proposition that interrogatories seeking to obtain the actual words used in a conversation are never permissible.

Interrogatories which are directed merely to matters affecting a party’s credibility are improper because they do not relate to matters in issue: Allhusen v Labouchere (1878) 3 QBD 654 at 661Â ; Coal Cliff Collieries Pty Ltd v CE Heath Insurance Broking (Aust) Pty Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 703 at 708–10Â .

level.toc-caption: [22.1.40] Defamation proceedings — interrogatories as to state of mind

heading.title: Defamation proceedings — interrogatories as to state of mind

p.text: Interrogatories often find a particular application in defamation proceedings where proof of matters such as the details of publication, the precise terms of the publication and the intention of the defendant have all been held to be proper subjects of interrogatories. Interrogatories may also be allowed that go to the question of damages — for example, the existence of complaints after the date of the alleged publication: Hansen v Border Morning Mail Pty Ltd (1987) 9 NSWLR 44 at 58Â . In most of these cases, the availability of interrogatories is simply a consequence of the application of the general principles to the particular issues in the proceedings. There are, however, at least two respects in which the use of interrogatories in proceedings for defamation merits particular comment. First, defamation proceedings constitute a significant exception to the general proposition that interrogatories directed to a party’s state of mind are generally not permissible — because they do not relate to a matter in question in the proceedings. For example, where the defence of comment of a servant is raised under Defamation Act 1974 s 33, interrogatories may be directed to the state of mind of the servant at the time of the making of the comment: Seidler v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 2 NSWLR 390 at 394Â . There are other ways in which intention may be relevant in defamation proceedings — and in respect of which interrogatories may be allowed: Norton v Hoare (No 2) (1913) 17 CLR 348Â (malice); Erwin v Southdown Press [1976] VR 353 at 355Â (intention that ambiguous words be taken to refer to plaintiff); Spasojevic v Riznic [1982] 1 NSWLR 278Â (defence of truth).

Sometimes the sources of a party’s knowledge may relate to a matter in issue in the proceedings and thus be a potential topic of interrogatories. However, if the party to be interrogated is a newspaper publisher, the courts are likely to disallow the interrogatories and to apply a rule of practice designed to protect the anonymity of the source of the information: McGuiness v A-G (Vic) (1940) 63 CLR 73 at 92; [1940] ALR 110Â ; John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Cojuangco (1988) 165 CLR 346 at 356; 82 ALR 1; BC8802649Â . The rule of practice will not necessarily be applied in all cases (Lyle-Samuel v Odhams Press Ltd [1920] 1 KB 135Â ) and it does not prevent disclosure of the nature of the information or the circumstances in which it was obtained: Wran v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1984] 3 NSWLR 241 at 250–1Â . The rule does not apply to
employees of the newspaper: Kerrisk v North Queensland Newspaper Co Ltd [1992] 2 Qd R 398; (1991) Aust Torts Reports Â¶ 81-129Â ;

contributors of defamatory letters published in the newspaper: Watt v David Syme & Co [1914] VLR 639; (1914) 20 ALR 379Â ; South Suburban Co-op Society Ltd v Orum [1937] 2 KB 690; [1937] 3 All ER 133Â ;
actions for breach of confidence: British Steel Corporation v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417; [1980] 3 WLR 774Â ;
actions for injurious falsehood: AMI Australia Holdings Pty Ltd v Fairfax Media Publications Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 1484; BC200912208Â at [51]–[53](further and better discovery granted).

There are many different aspects of a document that may become relevant to the proceedings. These include their contents, authorship, receipt, possession or existence. In determining whether any particular interrogatory is permissible it is essential to identify the aspect of relevance that is contended for and then to apply basic principles. For example, an interrogatory as to the content of an existing document will generally be disallowed — because of the best evidence rule ie, the document speaks for itself: Winterbottom v Vardon & Sons Ltd [1921] SASR 364Â . But that rule cannot apply where the document has been lost or destroyed and, accordingly, interrogatories will be allowed as to the contents of such a document: Norton v Hoare (No 2) (1913) 17 CLR 348 at 345Â ; Giasoumi v Hutton [1977] VR 294Â . On the other hand, an interrogatory may be permissible if its real purpose is to obtain a specific admission about the contents of a document: Dalrymple v Leslie (1881) 8 QBD 5 (contents of letters); Dunbar v Perc [1956] VLR 583Â (contents of depositions of a coronial inquest). If the document requires explanation before it can be understood, then interrogatories may be allowed: Becker v Smith’s Newspapers Ltd (No 1) [1931] SASR 1Â (signs, abbreviations and non-English words); Sharpe v Smail (1975) 5 ALR 377; 49 ALJR 130Â (meaning of words); but cf Chan v Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (1983) 49 ALR 593Â . A party may be interrogated as to whether it wrote a particular document, or whether a specified document was prepared or sent with its consent, or received by it: Lyell v Kennedy (No 4) (1884) 33 WR 44Â ; King v Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd (1921) 29 CLR 141; [1921] VLR 126Â ; Jordan v Sanders [1934] SASR 424Â ; American Flange & Manufacturing Co Inc v Rheem (Aust) Pty Ltd (No 2) [1965] NSWR 193Â . A party may also be interrogated as to whether a particular document was the source of some specific information: Cumming v Matheson (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 339Â . This, however, is subject to the restriction that interrogatories will not be permitted to operate as a form of cross-examination as to the adequacy of discovery. Thus, a party cannot generally be interrogated as to the documents that have been in its possession: Hall v Truman, Hanbury & Co (1885) 29 Ch D 307Â ; Danby v Australian Financial Agency and Guarantee Co Ltd (1891) 17 VLR 156Â .

Interrogatories will not be ordered as to the manner in which a party intends to prove their case: West v Conway (1923) 23 SR (NSW) 344 at 347Â ; or as to the witnesses to be called: Knapp v Harvey [1911] 2 KB 725 at 732Â ; Lever v Associated Newspapers [1907] 2 KB 626 at 628Â . As a matter of practice, however, the distinction (between interrogatories about facts and those about evidence) is not always so easy to make (see Herald & Weekly Times Ltd v Hawke [1984] VR 587 at 591Â ; Barbarian Motor Cycle Club Inc v Koithan (1984) 35 SASR 481Â ), and there are apparent inconsistencies in the way in which it is applied. One obvious and necessary erosion of the proposition is that an interrogatory that is properly directed to a relevant matter of fact cannot be objected to on the basis that its answer would require the incidental disclosure of the names of witnesses: Marriott v Chamberlain (1886) 17 QBD 154Â ; Fischer v City Hotels Pty Ltd (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 322Â (interrogatory as to the parties to an oral contract); contrast Cumming v Matheson (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 339Â ; Elliott Bros v Bonnington (1893) 10 WN (NSW) 46. But, as will be obvious, the judgment as to what is a “necessary” interrogatory in such a case, and whether the disclosure of “evidence” is merely incidental, will depend not only upon the objective circumstances but also upon the court’s perception of the real importance of the matter for the litigation as a whole. Given the nature of the judgment involved it is not surprising that one can find a degree of variability in the decisions which purport to embrace the distinction between “facts” and “evidence”.

It is fundamental that the interrogatories be drafted with sufficient care and skill. The drafting must achieve two goals. First, it must demonstrate that the interrogatory relates to a matter in issue. This goal is not met if, for example, the interrogatory merely seeks an admission that material is “relevant to the matters in issue”, and such an interrogatory is not permissible: Seidler v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1983] 2 NSWLR 390 at 392Â . The second goal that is sought to be achieved is to compel an answer in terms that will constitute an admission that will be of advantage to the interrogator. Consequently it is important that interrogatories be framed in such a way as to produce a clear answer: Hawke v Tamworth Newspaper Co Ltd [1983] 1 NSWLR 699Â . The interrogatories should be numbered consecutively. Each one should be as shortly and plainly worded as possible. None should assume the existence of any fact that has not been admitted either in the pleadings or in an earlier answer: Winterbottom v Vardon & Sons Ltd [1921] SASR 364 at 367Â ; Konings v Naylor [1964] Qd R 235Â (objection to interrogatories upheld); Thiess v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (No 3) [1992] 1 Qd R 587Â (objection insufficient unless the interrogatory was unfair or oppressive).

In the drafting of interrogatories it has been said that the test of their propriety is whether the witness could be asked the question in examination in chief if called as a witness for the interrogating party: Dunbar v Perc [1956] VLR 583 at 591Â ; Lyell v Kennedy (1883) 8 App Cas 217 at 234Â ; Hawkes v Schubach [1953] VLR 468 at 471Â ; Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) v BR Yuill (No 4) (1991) 5 ACSR 758 at 762Â . However an interrogatory is not improper merely because it is in a form that amounts to cross-examination. The real test of the permissibility of the interrogatory is necessity. If the answer sought is material and necessary it does not matter whether the question is in the nature of cross-examination: Kennedy v Dodson [1895] 1 Ch 334 at 341Â ; Coal Cliff Collieries Pty Ltd v CE Heath Insurance Broking (Aust) Pty Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 703 at 708–10Â .

level.toc-caption: [22.1.70] Law — interrogatories relating to matters of

heading.title: Law — interrogatories relating to matters of

p.text: Parties are not required to plead matters of law and witnesses, unless they are qualified as experts, cannot be asked questions at trial relating to questions of law. Correspondingly, it has been said that interrogatories that require a party to form an opinion on a matter of law are not generally permissible: McBride v Sandland [1917] SALR 249Â ; Coal Cliff Collieries Pty Ltd v CE Heath Insurance Broking (Aust) Pty Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 703Â ; King v Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd (1921) 29 CLR 141; [1921] VLR 126Â . However, the authorities on this issue are not conclusive (Norton v Hoare (No 2) (1913) 17 CLR 348 at 352Â ) and, in any event, the distinction between matters of fact and law is notoriously difficult to draw. Accordingly it would be a mistake to approach the matter on the basis that an interrogatory will be improper whenever it is possible to discern that an answer will involve some matter that can be characterised as one of law: Lester v DH & LS Chilcott & Son Pty Ltd (1991) 9 ACLC 605 at 613Â (interlocutory allowed as to whether a debt was due for payment). Probably the true position, as was suggested in Coal Cliff Collieries , above at 708, is that in the ordinary case an interrogatory that involves a question of law alone will rarely satisfy the test of necessity.

Another proper purpose of interrogatories is to obtain particulars of the material facts relevant to the proceedings: Ashley v Taylor (1878) 38 LT 44. Interrogatories of this type enable a party to appreciate the nature of the opposing parties case and are really in the nature of a request for further and better particulars: Green v Green (1912) 13 SR (NSW) 126 at 132Â ; Saunders v Jones (1877) 7 Ch D 435Â . Thus it is not a valid objection to this type of interrogatory that the particulars sought are facts tending to support the case of the party being interrogated: Cumming v Matheson (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 339 at 342–3Â . For three examples of this class of interrogatories, see Cameron v Cameron (1890) 7 WN (NSW) 29; Bellambi Coal Co Ltd v Barry (1904) 4 SR (NSW) 748Â ; West v Conway (1923) 23 SR (NSW) 344Â ; Fischer v City Hotels Pty Ltd (1970) 92 WN (NSW) 322Â . But while interrogatories of this type are permissible, there is some disinclination to allow them: Davey v Danby (1887) 9 ALJ 100; Ryan v Federal Capital Press of Australia Pty Ltd (1990) 101 FLR 396Â ; Pearce v Hall (1989) 52 SASR 568 at 572Â ; Western Australian Capital Investment Co Ltd v FCT 88 ATC 4562. And, given the specific power conferred by r 15.10 to order a party to provide particulars, it may be doubtful whether it would ever be “necessary” to make an order under the present rule, as distinct from an order under rÂ 15.10. Perhaps for that reason it has been said that even where interrogatories in the nature of particulars are allowed it seems, the answers ought not be required to be verified: Conde vÂ 2KY Broadcasters Pty Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 221Â .

level.toc-caption: [22.1.80] State of mind, purpose or motive

heading.title: State of mind, purpose or motive

p.text: Interrogatories as to purpose or motive are generally impermissible: Service v Coote (1891) 17 VLR 40Â ; Navair Pty Ltd v Transport Workers’ Union of Australia (1981) 52 FLR 177 at 195Â ; cf Jordan v Sanders [1934] SASR 424Â . But this is because questions of motive or purpose are themselves generally irrelevant to the substantive issues in the proceedings; see for example, Bodalla Co Pty Ltd v Dairy Farmers’ Co-op (1988) 15 ACLR 478 at 482Â . If, in the particular proceedings, the motive or state of mind of the parties is a material fact then interrogatories directed to those matters may properly be administered: Rofe v Kevorkian [1936] 2 All ER 1334Â ; Bodalla Co Pty Ltd v Dairy Farmers’ Co-op , above, at 482; Aspar Autobarn Co-op Society v Dovala Pty Ltd (1987) 16 FCR 284; 74 ALR 550 at 551Â . (Proceedings involving allegations of fraud provide a clear example of a situation where the defendant’s state of mind is a material issue on which interrogatories will be allowed: Hawkes v Schubach [1953] VLR 468 at 472Â .) If the relevant state of mind is that of a corporation, then interrogatories may be ordered to determine the state of mind of the particular officers by whom the corporation acted in relation to relevant matter: Wildia Pty Ltd v Lee (1984) 9 ACLR 122Â ; Bodalla Co Pty Ltd v Dairy Farmers’ Co-op , above, at 482; cf Tooth & Co Ltd v Lane Cove Municipal Council (No 4) [1968] 2 NSWR 17Â (no interrogatories as to the “corporate” state of mind).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 22.2] r 22.2 Objections to specific interrogatories (cf SCR Part 24, ruleÂ 6(3))

leg:heading.title: Objections to specific interrogatories (cf SCR Part 24, ruleÂ 6(3))

p.text: A party may not object to being ordered to answer an interrogatory except on the following grounds:
the interrogatory does not relate to any matter in issue between that party and the party seeking the order,
the interrogatory is vexatious or oppressive,
the answer to the interrogatory could disclose privileged information.

Oppression is not a precisely defined concept. It may include concepts such as unduly burdensome obligations: (Aspar Autobarn Co-op Society v Dovala Pty Ltd (1987) 16 FCR 284; 74 ALR 550 at 554–5Â ; American Flange & Manufacturing Co Inc v Rheem (Aust) Pty Ltd (No 2) [1965] NSWR 193 at 195Â (excessive number of interrogatories); Southern Pacific Hotel Services Inc 9 v Southern Pacific Hotel Corp Ltd (NSWSC, Foster J, 10 December 1984, unreported, BC8400131) (excessive number); Hughes v Western Australian Cricket Assn Inc (1986) ATPR Â¶40-748 (enquiries of numerous volunteer workers); Parker v Wells (1881) 18 Ch D 477Â (search of old records); disclosure of trade secrets: Ashworth v Roberts (1890) 45 Ch D 623Â ; Potters Sulphide Ore Treatment Ltd v Sulphide Corp Ltd (1911) 13 CLR 101; 18 ALR 141; Printers & Finishers Ltd v Holloway [1964] 3 All ER 731Â (order for inspection by expert)), insufficient relevance, improper purpose and substantive unfairness. In relation to all but the last of these concepts it is doubtful whether the question of oppression raises any consideration broader than the issue of “necessity” that arises in relation to r 22.1. For example, in White & Co v Credit Reform Assn [1905] 1 KB 653Â , interrogatories requiring disclosure of the names of all the purchasers of a defamatory book were refused as oppressive but the result would no doubt have been the same if the requirement of “necessity” had been applied. However, that requirement will not be sufficient to protect the interrogated party from substantive unfairness. Although the instances in which this question may arise will probably not be frequent, one possible illustration is where an interrogatory is sought to be administered for the purpose of obtaining an acknowledgment of an otherwise statute-barred debt: Lovell v Lovell [1970] 3 All ER 721; [1970] 1 WLR 1451Â ; cf Giasoumi v Hutton [1977] VR 294Â (interrogatory allowed for the purpose of proving the prior existence of a written contract).
Legislation cited in [22.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.5.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 87.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ssÂ 126A-126F.

The question whether privilege affords a proper basis for a complete refusal to answer depends on the nature of the privilege claimed. Privilege is discussed generally in the notes to the discovery rules and, in particular, the notes to r 21.5 . Where the objection is based on the privilege against incrimination, the effect of the objection will depend on the exercise of the courts powers under s 87 of the CPA: see the notes to that section. It is a ground of objection to an interrogatory that the answer could disclose a protected confidence (under Part 3.10 Division 1A ( ssÂ 126A-126F ) of the Evidence Act 1995) and that consent has not been given to the disclosure: Kadian v Richards (2004) 61 NSWLR 222; [2004] NSWSC 382; BC200403813Â (doctor/patient confidentiality).

level.toc-caption: [22.2.15] Objections to interrogatories — answers given “subject to objection”

heading.title: Objections to interrogatories — answers given “subject to objection”

p.text: There have been instances where the answering party has stated an objection to the interrogatory and then proceeded to provide a substantive answer “under the cover of” the objection. Where an answer is prefaced by an objection of that kind, the objection is ineffective and the answer may still be tendered: Mitchell v Tsiros (No 1) [1982] VR 191Â . The making of such an objection is not necessary to preserve the answering party’s right to argue the question of relevance when the answer is tendered at the trial: Re Barned’s Banking Co; Ex parte Contract Corp (1867) LR 2 Ch App 350 at 354; Mitchell v Tsiros (No 1), above at 192.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 22.3] r 22.3 Answers to interrogatories (cf SCR Part 24, rules 4 and 6; DCR Part 22A, rules 4 and 6)

leg:heading.title: Answers to interrogatories (cf SCR Part 24, rules 4 and 6; DCR Part 22A, rules 4 and 6)

p.text: A party who has been ordered to answer interrogatories must do so within the time required by the order by serving a statement of answers on all other active parties.
Such a statement:
must deal with each interrogatory specifically, setting out each interrogatory followed by the answer to it, and
must answer the substance of each interrogatory without evasion, and
to the extent to which, and in the manner in which, the order so requires, must be verified by affidavit.
See rule 22.6 as to the admission in evidence of answers to interrogatories.
The approved form is Form 22 : Statement in Answer to Interrogatories.

level.toc-caption: [22.3.10] The form of answers to interrogatories

heading.title: The form of answers to interrogatories

p.text: The statement in answer to interrogatories must set out the interrogatory first and then the answer: see Court Forms Precedents & Pleadings (NSW), LexisNexis Butterworths, (looseleaf), vol 1, guide card “Discovery, Inspection & Interrogatories”, precedent 20.45. However, a failure to observe this requirement will not necessarily justify an order for further answers: Bristow v Australian Chemical Co Pty Ltd [1957] QWN 13Â ). But a purported answer will be regarded as improperly evasive if it merely refers the interrogator to the contents of other documents, books or affidavits for the substance of the information that has been sought: Inglessi v Spartali (1861) 54 ER 747; Drake v Symes (1859) 70 ER 578; Turner v Jack (1871) 19 WR 433.

level.toc-caption: [22.3.15] Answering the substance of the interrogatory without evasion

p.text: Legislation cited in [22.3.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 22.6(1)(b).

heading.title: Answering the substance of the interrogatory without evasion

p.text: Each interrogatory must be answered and the answer must address, without evasion, the substance of the question asked: Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) (1884) 50 LT 730; 27 Ch D 1 at 16Â ; Parker v Wells (1881) 18 Ch D 477 at 487Â . The actual form of the answer may, however, depend to a degree upon the nature of the question that has been asked. Sometimes a direct “yes” or “no” answer may be all that is required, or allowed, by the form of the question: Winterbottom v Vardon & Sons Ltd [1921] SASR 364Â . In other instances a general answer will suffice if the interrogatory is general (Gordon & Co v Bank of England (1844) 8 Jur 1132), but not if the interrogatory is specific: Earp v Lloyd (1858) 70 ER 24; Brunswick v Cambridge (1849) 50 ER 1068. In either case, a conditional answer will usually be bad: Cayron v Russell (1898) 24 VLR 69Â . Where a simple direct answer could be misleading to evasive, any reasonable explanation or qualifications may be added: Lyell v Kennedy (No 4) (1884) 33 WR 44Â ; Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) (1884) 50 LT 730; 27 Ch D 1 at 14Â . But the explanation must not introduce irrelevant or superfluous matter that would prevent use of the answer at the trial: Peyton v Harting (1873) LR 9 CP 9; but see UCPR r 22.6(1)(b) . And the answer, apart from the qualification, must be responsive to the question asked: Bally v Kenrick and James (1824) 147 ER 994. If the substance of the interrogatory has been properly answered the addition of irrelevant qualifications or explanations will not justify an order for a further answer, because r 22.6(1)(b) allows the tender of part, as opposed to the whole, of an answer.

level.toc-caption: [22.3.20] Agents and servants — obligation to enquire of

heading.title: Agents and servants — obligation to enquire of

p.text: If a party is interrogated as to their own personal knowledge, the answer may be given without enquiry of others: Rasbotham v Shropshire Union Railways & Canal Co (1883) 24 Ch D 110Â . But in all other instances the party interrogated must make enquiries of their servants or agents if the interrogatories relate to matters of which they are likely to have become aware in the course of their “employment” by the party interrogated: Bolckow v Fisher (1882) 10 QBD 161 at 169Â ; Anderson v Bank of British Columbia (1876) 2 Ch D 644 at 657, 659Â ; Welsbach Incandescent Gas Light Co v New Sunlight Incandescent Co [1900] 2 Ch 1 at 10, 11Â . For the purpose of defining the extent of the obligation to enquire, the word “agents” includes bankers, solicitors and co-trustees: Alliott v Smith [1895] 2 Ch 111Â ; National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia v Christian [1933] ALR 111Â ; but not medical practitioners examining a patient or making a judgment about the patient’s condition or treatment: Kadian v Richards (2004) 61 NSWLR 222; [2004] NSWSC 382; BC200403813Â (doctor/patient confidentiality). A party should expressly state in their answer that they have made enquiries of their servant and agents — in any event where the answer is limited in some way: Ormond v Gunnersen [1920] VLR 402Â ; City Newspaper Co Ltd v Evening Standard Newspaper Co Ltd (1891) 17 VLR 368Â ; Sharpe v Smail (1975) 5 ALR 377; 49 ALJR 130Â ; but it is not necessary to set out the details of the enquiries that have been made: Stanfield Properties Ltd v National Westminster Bank Plc [1983] 2 All ER 249; [1983] 1 WLR 568 at 570Â . A party may be excused from answering if their agent’s knowledge was acquired accidentally or not in the ordinary course of their employment: McMeckan v Aitken (1891) 17 VLR 301Â ; Commissioner for Railways v South Queensland Transport Pty Ltd [1950] QWN 45Â ; Bolckow v Fisher (1882) 10 QBD 161Â . At least this will be so if the information was acquired by the servant or agent in a personal capacity and is not information that the person was obliged to use for the benefit of the employer principal: Smith Kline & French Laboratories Ltd v Inter-Continental Pharmaceuticals (Aust) Pty Ltd (1969) 123 CLR 514 at 522; 43 ALJR 308Â per Windeyer J (consideration of the position of a director in relation to interlocking corporations); Adams v Dickeson [1974] VR 77 at 81Â .

level.toc-caption: [22.3.25] Agents and servants – obligation to enquire of former

heading.title: Agents and servants – obligation to enquire of former

p.text: It is not sufficient to excuse an answer that an employee is no longer in the service or control of the party being interrogated unless it would be unreasonable because of the length of time since the employee has departed or the expense in locating them: National Trustees Executors & Agency Co of Australasia v Christian [1933] ALR 111Â ; Sharpe v Smail (1975) 5 ALR 377 at 379; 49 ALJR 130Â ; Derham v AMEV Life Insurance Co Ltd (1978) 20 ACTR 23Â and Stanfield Properties Ltd v National Westminster Bank Plc [1983] 2 All ER 249; [1983] 1 WLR 568Â . See also Little v TK Bennett & Woolcock Ltd (1900) 25 VLR 645Â . An interrogated party is bound to make reasonable enquiries “the pursuit of ancient history” is not required: Stanfield Properties Ltd v National Westminster Bank Plc [1983] 2 All ER 249; [1983] 1 WLR 568 at 570Â .

The person verifying the corporation’s answers must answer from both their own individual knowledge and from such information as they can gain from other servants of the company who may have personal knowledge of the facts: Bank of Russian Trade Ltd v British Screen Productions Ltd [1930] 2 KB 90. A corporation’s answer to interrogatories should state that after making all proper enquiries the answers filed are true and correct to the best of the corporation’s knowledge, information and belief: Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd v Whinfield [1920] VLR 225 at 229; (1920) 26 ALR 144Â ; Gilchrist v Wallace Mitchell Pty Ltd [1972] VR 481Â ; Sharpe v Smail (1975) 5 ALR 377; 49 ALJR 130Â . In determining whether any particular knowledge and information is that of the corporation, the traditional view was that the corporation was not bound to make enquiries about information that employees gained otherwise than in the course of their employment: Welsbach Incandescent Gas Light Co v New Sunlight Incandescent Co [1900] 2 Ch 1Â ; Bank of Russian Trade Ltd v British Screen Productions , above at 95. However, Smith Kline & French Laboratories Ltd v Inter-Continental Pharmaceuticals (Aust) Pty Ltd (1969) 123 CLR 514 at 522; 43 ALJR 308Â per Windeyer J, suggests the wider view that the proper officer in answering interrogatories on behalf of his company should answer according to any knowledge that they have of its affairs, however it was gained, if it was knowledge that they would be bound to use in the discharge of their duties as an officer of the corporation.

In actions by or against a corporation that is in liquidation, the opposite party has the same right to obtain discovery or to interrogate as would be the case with any other litigant: Re Barned’s Banking Co; Ex parte Contract Corp (1867) LR 2 Ch App 350; Re Contract Corp (1872) LR 7 Ch App 207 (Gooch's case). And the liquidator may be required to make enquiries of former employees and agents for the purpose of answering the interrogatories: Sharpe v Smail (1975) 5 ALR 377; 49 ALJR 130Â ; Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) v Bank of New Zealand (1992) 27 NSWLR 73; 6 ACSR 416. A liquidator who has a statutory power to conduct examination of company officers, is not obliged to exercise that power before answering interrogatories: Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) v Bank of New Zealand (1992) 27 NSWLR 73; 6 ACSR 416. As to the related question of discovery where a party has a statutory entitlement to obtain documents, see the notes to r 21 of the UCPR.

A party to litigation, against a nominal defendant appointed pursuant to the Crown Proceedings Act 1988 has the same rights to discovery and interrogation as he would have had against an ordinary subject: Commonwealth v Miller (1910) 10 CLR 742; [1911] VLR 60Â (see especially Isaacs J at 753), distinguishing Commonwealth v Baume (1904) 2 CLR 405; 11 ALR 124; Ricketson v Smith (1896) 17 LR (NSW) Eq 203; Morrissey v Young (1896) 17 LR (NSW) Eq 157Â ; Bank of New South Wales v Dibbs (1885) 2 WN (NSW) 9; Jamison v Downie [1923] AC 691Â (Privy Council). Section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth) confers the same rights upon a litigant against the Commonwealth: R v Associated Northern Collieries (1910) 11 CLR 738; 17 ALR 359Â ; Heimann v Commonwealth (1935) 54 CLR 126; [1935] ALR 501Â per Evatt J.

If, despite proper enquiries having being made, the answer is limited, then the party answering should say “save as stated I am unable to answer this interrogatory further from knowledge, information or belief”: Dooly v Oldman [1949] ALR (CN) 1053. If the party is unable to answer at all, the response to the interrogatory must state that the party has no personal knowledge and no information nor any belief derived from his servants or agents: Hawkes v Schubach [1953] VLR 468 at 472Â . It is not a sufficient answer to an interrogatory to say merely that the interrogated party does not know the answer: Adams v Dickeson [1974] VR 77Â . Similarly an answer as to knowledge and belief only is insufficient: Grassmere Estate Co Ltd v Illingworth (1889) 15 ALT 687. So also is an answer merely as to belief: Douglas v Morning Post (1923) 39 TLR 402Â ; or as to opinion: May v Bowering [1928] SASR 226Â .

The party interrogated must answer to the best of their knowledge information and belief: Douglas v Morning Post (1923) 39 TLR 402Â ; Lyell v Kennedy (No 2) (1883) 9 App Cas 92; Foakes v Webb (1884) 28 Ch D 287 at 289Â ; Hoffman v Postill (1869) LR 4 Ch App 673; Hawkes v Schubach [1953] VLR 468Â ; Kupresak v Clifton Bricks (Canberra) Pty Ltd (1984) 57 ACTR 32Â (answer as to belief). For this purpose “knowledge” includes conclusions that should reasonably be derived from other facts: Adams v Dickeson [1974] VR 77 at 80, 81Â . To offer an opinion upon the matter asked is generally insufficient: May v Bowering [1928] SASR 226. And an answer as to belief is generally treated as admission of the fact: Shannon v Whiting (1900) 26 VLR 392Â . Although a party has no obligation to answer interrogatories relating to matters to which they are a stranger (Weingarten v Wills [1903] SALR 142Â ; Amhurst v King (1825) 57 ER 315), the obligation to answer according to knowledge information and belief may mean that the interrogated party has to find or consider documents: Looker v Murphy (1889) 15 VLR 348Â (read depositions); Dalrymple v Leslie (1881) 8 QBD 5; or otherwise refresh recollection before answering: Sroka v Gorball & Scott (1980) 25 SASR 356Â (revisit accident scene).

Subtle differences can arise in distinguishing between the knowledge and belief. The problem can arise in several different situations — where different employees or agents have different recollections of particular events or where the employer or principal does not believe what the employee or agent says. The problem arises because a person will generally be regarded as having the knowledge of any of the agents (at least so long as the knowledge was gained in the course of their employment). On the other hand, “belief” is essentially a subjective concept and a person cannot be compelled to embrace a belief, however reasonable the basis for it might appear to be, that is not honestly and actually held: Makim v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1990) 5 BR 196 at 200. This is particularly so in the case of a person who answers interrogatories on behalf of a corporation. The person cannot be required to profess a belief in the truth of information supplied by the servants or agents of the corporation unless the person is actually satisfied that the information is accurate — although the person cannot withhold satisfaction merely on the ground of baseless suspicion: Gilchrist v Wallace Mitchell Pty Ltd [1972] VR 481 at 483Â ; Sharpe v Smail (1975) 5 ALR 377 at 380; 49 ALJR 130Â .

The obligation to enquire of servants and agents will be ineffective to produce appropriate answers if the nominal party is not the person actually conducting the proceedings — as will be the case, for example, where an insurer is either conducting the defence or exercising a right of subrogation. In these situations, at least where it can be shown that the insurer has the means of obtaining the information sought, default orders may be made if proper answers are not made to the interrogatories: Treiguts v Tweedley [1959] VR 544; [1959] ALR 1050Â ; Dalywater v Dalywater (1984) 30 NTR 14; 73 FLR 55Â ; Lovell v Millhouse [1989] Tas R 101; (1989) 9 MVR 390Â . Where the actual defendant is a mere nominee, for example in proceedings involving uninsured or unidentified motor vehicles, there will often be little utility in a plaintiff seeking to administer interrogatories about the circumstances giving rise to the claim. But interrogatories that go to establishing compliance with any procedural requirements necessary to give rise to an enforceable right against the nominal party may be allowed: Mildred v Cuthell (1986) 43 SASR 145Â .

Rule 22.1 applies to disabled persons under legal incapacity and their tutor, despite the general position that legal incapacity would otherwise preclude minors and persons of unsound mind from being interrogated: Mayor v Collins (1890) 24 QBD 361; Ingram v Little (1883) 11 QBD 251Â . If the tutor answers interrogatories, the disabled person may not also be interrogated. The tutor of any infant plaintiff is not required to answer interrogatories according to their personal knowledge as distinct from the knowledge of the plaintiff: Jackson v Roberts (1941) ALR (CN) 365. However, in Rogers v Wentworth (NSWSC, 26 March 1984, unreported), Master Gressier declined to follow the decision in Jackson v Roberts , above.

Rule 22.1(5)(b) gives the court power to order that the answers to interrogatories, or any of them, be verified by affidavit. The court may specify the person by whom the affidavit is to be made where the answering party is a corporation, the crown or a person under legal incapacity: see rr 22.(5)(c) and r 35.3(1). In the case of a corporation, the most appropriate deponent is usually either the general manager or some other senior officer who is in a position to obtain and carefully weigh all the information available with respect to the matters enquired after: Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd v Whinfield [1920] VLR 225; (1920) 26 ALR 144Â . The secretary of the corporation will often be an appropriate person to swear the affidavit verifying the answers to interrogatories: Berkeley v Standard Discount Co (1879) 13 Ch D 97 at 99Â ; Re Alexandra Palace Co (1880) 16 Ch D 58 at 59Â ; Attorney-General v North Metropolitan Tramways Co [1892] 3 Ch 70Â . If the subject matter of the interrogatories concerns the details of a technical or manufacturing process, then the proper officer to make the affidavit verifying discovery may be a manager of the manufacturing process: Welsbach Incandescent Gas Light Co v New Sunlight Incandescent Co [1900] 2 Ch 1 at 12Â ; Smith Kline & French Laboratories Ltd v Inter-Continental Pharmaceuticals (Aust) Pty Ltd (1969) 123 CLR 514; 43 ALJR 308Â . The fact that a party wants to obtain answers to the same interrogatories from a different officer of the corporation, will not warrant an order to administer a second set of interrogatories: Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd v Whinfield , above, at 310.

The affidavit verifying a corporation’s answers to interrogatories should not be sworn by an ordinary member of the corporation unless: (1) there is no officer with competent knowledge of the facts; and (2) the proposed member has the means of answering: Berkeley v Standard Discount Co (1879) 13 Ch D 97Â . Where the court is to be asked to specify an ordinary member of the corporation to make the affidavit (under r 7(2)(a)) that member should be served with notice of the application: Chaddock v British South Africa Co [1896] 2 QB 153 at 155Â . It is unnecessary to give such a notice to an officer of the corporation: Chaddock , above at 155. See also Smith Kline & French Laboratories Ltd v Inter-Continental Pharmaceuticals (Aust) Pty Ltd , above, CLR at 522.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 22.4] r 22.4 Insufficient answer (cf SCR Part 24, rule 8; DCR Part 22A, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Insufficient answer (cf SCR Part 24, rule 8; DCR Part 22A, rule 8)

p.text: If a party who has been ordered to answer interrogatories under rule 22.1 fails to answer an interrogatory sufficiently within the time specified in the order or, if no such time is specified, within 28 days after being served with the order, the court:
may order the party to make a further answer, and to verify that further answer by affidavit, or
may order the party or, as the case requires, any person of the kind referred to in rule 35.3(1), to attend to be orally examined.
This rule does not limit the power of the court under rule 22.5.

The sufficiency of the answers is determined having regard to the requirements of the rules, to the form of the interrogatories and to the form and content of the proffered answers. So far as the interrogatories are concerned, an order requiring further answers will not be made where the interrogatories are not clearly expressed: Hawke v Tamworth Newspaper Co Ltd [1983] 1 NSWLR 699 at 707Â . Depending upon the particular interrogatory, an answer may be sufficient even though it does not specifically answer every aspect of the interrogatory: Bolckow v Fisher (1882) 10 QBD 161 at 170Â . If the substance of the interrogatory has been answered, purely technical deficiencies in the form of the answer will not afford a basis for an order requiring further answers: Parker v Wells (1881) 18 Ch D 477 at 487Â ; Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) (1884) 50 LT 730; 27 Ch D 1 at 16Â . So far as the answers are concerned, the assessment of their sufficiency does not generally involve any consideration of their objective truth: Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) , above; McBride v Sandland [1917] SALR 249 at 262Â ; Mulley v Manifold (1959) 103 CLR 341 at 345; 33 ALJR 168; BC5900640Â . (Although if it were apparent, either from the answers as a whole, or from the pleadings, from documents to which reference is made in the answers or from the nature of the interrogatory or the objection, that the answers could not in fact have been provided to the best of the knowledge, information and belief of the interrogated party, that inconsistency could be relied upon to demonstrate the insufficiency of the answer: Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) , above at 21; Wainman v Hansen (1884) 6 ALT 67.) If the answer is insufficient because it is not responsive to the interrogatory or includes superfluous information, a further answer may be ordered that eliminates embarrassing or superfluous matter: King v Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd (1921) 29 CLR 141; [1921] VLR 126Â ; Peyton v Harting (1873) LR 9 CP 9; Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) , above, at 28 (material so involved as to be incapable of being used). An application to make further answers to interrogatories should be made by way of Notice of Motion, specifying the particular answers which are objected to (Anstey v North and South Woolwich Subway Co (1879) 11 Ch D 439Â ; Smith v Ison (1888) 10 ALT 4Â ; Bennett v Morris (1887) 9 ALT 10) unless all of the answers are objected to: Furber v King (1881) 50 LJ Ch 496.

An application for an order requiring further answers to interrogatories should be made by motion in accordance with rr 18.2 and 18.3 of the UCPR. The motion should specify the particular answers alleged to be insufficient: Anstey v North and South Woolwich Subway Co (1879) 11 Ch D 439Â ; Smith & Ison (1888) 10 ALT 4Â ; Bennett v Morris (1887) 9 ALT 10; unless all the answers are objected to: Furber v King (1881) 17 Ch D 191Â .

An order for the oral examination of the interrogated party will rarely be made. In order to justify such an order it would usually be necessary to show that the unanswered interrogatories were clearly framed, that they had been insufficiently answered, that the deficiency in the answer was substantial and that there was no reasonable explanation for the failure to provide a proper answer: Warnecke v Darbyshire (1905) 27 ALT (Supp) 10; 11 ALR (CN) 64. Any oral examination that takes place should be limited to obtaining proper answers to the relevant interrogatories: Litchfield v Jones (1884) 54 LJ Ch 207. In its general discretion to award costs the court may order the examined party to pay the costs of the application and oral examination, in any event: Vicary v Great Northern Railway Co (1882) 9 QBD 168Â .

If a party who has been ordered to answer interrogatories under rule 22.1 or 22.4 fails to answer an interrogatory sufficiently, the court may give or make such judgment or such order as it thinks fit, including:
if the party in default is a plaintiff, an order that the proceedings be stayed or dismissed as to the whole or any part of the relief claimed by the party in the proceedings, or
if the proceedings were commenced by statement of claim and the party in default is a defendant, an order that the party’s defence be struck out.
If a party has a solicitor, an order under rule 22.1 or 22.4 need not, for the purposes of enforcement of the order by committal or sequestration, be served personally.

If an order under rule 22.1 or 22.4 is not served personally on a party having a solicitor, the order may not be enforced by committal of any person, or by sequestration of any person’s property, if that person shows that he or she did not have notice of the order within sufficient time to comply with the order.

The court has a discretion to stay proceedings or dismiss the whole or part of the claim where the plaintiff is in default in answering interrogatories: Hartley v Owen (1876) 34 LT 752Â ; Kennedy v Lyell [1882] WN 137; Treiguts v Tweedley [1959] VR 544; [1959] ALR 1050Â . The exercise of that discretion is subject to the general proposition that a court should not take the extreme course of striking out on account of a failure to comply with an interlocutory order, unless it is the only way to ensure effective compliance with the court’s procedures: Mosser v PGH Ceramics Pty Ltd (1964) 82 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 147Â per Walsh J. A dismissal order will accordingly be made if the default is intentional (Danvillier v Myers [1883] WN 58; Haigh v Haigh (1885) 31 Ch D 478Â ), but not if there is a reasonable excuse for the failure to answer: Cardwell v Tomlinson (1885) 54 LJ Ch 957; James Nelson & Sons Ltd v Nelson Line (Liverpool) Ltd [1906] 2 KB 217 at 227Â ; Wilson v Raffalovich (1881) 7 QBD 553 at 561Â ; Treiguts v Tweedley, above.

The motion to have a defence struck out for non-compliance with an order to answer interrogatories may seek orders, that judgment be entered in default of a defence (Gamble v Killingsworth & McLean Publishing Co Pty Ltd [1970] VR 161 at 170Â ) or that a trustee be removed: Fisher v Hughes (1877) 25 WR 528Â . An order dismissing proceedings or striking out a defence need not be served: Farden v Richter (1889) 23 QBD 124Â .

The order for dismissal may be made contingent upon failure to answer within a further time, and if the answer is not given the action is at an end: Whistler v Hancock (1878) 3 QBD 83Â ; King v Davenport (1879) 4 QBD 402Â ; Mosser v PGH Ceramics Pty Ltd (1964) 82 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 147Â ; Re Macintosh & Thomas [1903] 2 Ch 394Â . However, the court retains a discretion to extend time for compliance pursuant to r 1.12, and in exercising that power prefers, if the balance of discretionary considerations otherwise permits, to allow proceedings to be heard on their merits: Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (1986) 7 NSWLR 319Â ; Morgan v 45 Flers Avenue Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 573 at 578, 580–1Â ; Paino v Hofbauer (1988) 13 NSWLR 193 at 196–7, 200Â ; FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268; 77 ALR 411; BC8802594Â . These authorities supersede the earlier cases in which the view had been taken that after time had expired, the court had no power to further extend time, as the action was no longer in existence (Carter v Stubbs (1880) 6 QBD 116 at 188Â (dismissal for want of prosecution); Johnson & Co Ltd v Clifford (1904) 7 WALR 130Â ; Pollard v Incorporated Nominal Defendant [1972] VR 955 at 962Â ; Bailey v Marinoff (1971) 125 CLR 529; [1972] ALR 259Â ); although application could be made to enlarge the time for appealing against the dismissal and then having allowed the appeal, the court could extend time: Burke v Rooney (1879) 4 CPD 226Â ; Johnson & Co Ltd v Clifford , above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 22.6] r 22.6 Answers to interrogatories as evidence (cf SCR Part 24, ruleÂ 10; DCR Part 22A, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Answers to interrogatories as evidence (cf SCR Part 24, ruleÂ 10; DCR Part 22A, rule 10)

p.text: A party:
may tender as evidence one or more answers to interrogatories without tendering the others, and
may tender as evidence part of an answer to an interrogatory without tendering the whole of the answer.
If the whole or part of an answer to an interrogatory is tendered as evidence, the court:
may look at the whole of the answer, and

if it appears to the court that any other answer or any part of an answer is so connected with the matter tendered that the matter tendered ought not to be used without that other answer or part, may reject the tender unless that other answer or part is also tendered.

level.toc-caption: [22.6.5] Admissibility and effect of answers to interrogatories

heading.title: Admissibility and effect of answers to interrogatories

p.text: Answers to interrogatories are admissible at the instance of the interrogating party, or another party in the same interest. The interrogated party cannot tender its own answers to interrogatories — because they are merely prior consistent statements. The admissibility of the answers turns upon their characterisation as informal admissions of fact made by the answering party. But unlike formal admissions in pleadings, they are merely part of the evidence. The answering party is not prevented from adducing contrary evidence: Stateliner Pty Ltd v Legal and General Assurance Society Ltd (1981) 29 SASR 16 at 46; 2 ANZ Ins Cas Â¶60-455Â . Even in the absence of contradictory evidence, the court is not obliged to act on the admission: Tomic v Limro Pty Ltd (1993) 47 FCR 414Â ; Gannon v Gannon (1971) 125 CLR 629 at 640; [1972] ALR 579Â — especially if the answer is based on belief rather than knowledge. Neither is the party who tenders the answers bound to accept their truthfulness and may either call contradictory evidence or submit that they should be disregarded: Endeavour Wines Ltd v Martin and Martin [1948] WN 338; (1948) 92 Sol Jo 574.

level.toc-caption: [22.6.10] Answers to interrogatories in other proceedings

heading.title: Answers to interrogatories in other proceedings

p.text: There is authority for the proposition that an examined copy of answers to interrogatories in other proceedings is admissible against the answering party — and without formal proof of their due execution: Fleet v Perrins (1868) LR 3 QB 536; 9 B & S 575. But this depends upon whether the answers were actually used in the other proceedings. Otherwise the use of the answers would, unless leave was granted, constitute an improper use of information obtained only for the purposes of use in connection with the earlier proceedings

level.toc-caption: [22.6.15] Collateral purposes — restriction against use of answers for

heading.title: Collateral purposes — restriction against use of answers for

p.text: Answers to interrogatories are subject to the implied limitation that they be used only for the purpose of the proceedings in which the interrogatories were administered. In this respect the use of answers to interrogatories is subject to the same principles that apply to disclosure of documents obtained on discovery: Harman v Secretary of State for the Home Dept [1983] 1 AC 280; [1982] 2 WLR 338Â (HL) on appeal from Home Office v Harman [1981] 1Â QB 534 (CA); and [23.3.36]. Accordingly, disclosure to a third person of the opposing party’s answers to interrogatories for purposes unconnected with proceedings in which they were given, constitutes contempt of court: Central Queensland Cement Pty Ltd v Hardy [1989] 2 Qd R 509 at 510–11Â (disclosure of a witness statement); Springfield Nominees Pty Ltd v Bridgelands Securities Ltd (1992) 36 FCR 217; 110 ALR 685 (disclosure of a witness statement); Ainsworth v Hanrahan (1991) 25 NSWLR 155 at 157, 164, 167, 169Â .

Answers to interrogatories, although verified and filed, do not automatically become evidence unless they are formally tendered and admitted at the hearing. Naturally the tendering party is entitled, within the limits of fairness, to tender only those answers to interrogatories that are probative of particular facts: Fleet v Perrins (1868) LR 3 QB 536 at 541; 9 B & S 575. There is no obligation to tender all of the answers. Furthermore, if the answer to a particular question is evasive or prolix, the judge may allow the tender to be confined to such of the material as contains a direct answer to the interrogatory: Lyell v Kennedy (No 3) (1884) 50 LT 730; 27 Ch D 1 at 29Â .
